data.title: the mark of zorro by mcculley johnston
data.meta_description: MARK OF ZORRO (THE); by McCulley, Johnston. New York: Grosset and Dunlap, 1952.  Hardcover. Fair +/Fair.  Gray and tan patterned paper covered boards, blue titles at spine, moderate to heavy shelf wear, rubbing and staining to corners and edges, heaviest wear to head and tail of spine, corners slightly cocked. Book body clean and tight, pages age-toned. B&W illustrated dust jacket shows heavy shelf wear, cracking and some tears to covers, edges, and corners, heaviest tearing/wear to head and tail of spine, red and black titles at front and worn spine...
data.text:
More Photos

The Mark of Zorro

by Johnston McCulley

Used

Hardcover

Show Details

Description:

Grosset & Dunlap, New York, unknown. Early Edition. Hardcover (Original Cloth). Good Condition/Good. JOHNSTON McCULLEY. The Mark of Zorro, New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1924.Octavo, dated 1924 but this resembles 1930s reprints and is certainly not a first edition, pp. viii, 300, red cloth boards with gilt lettering to spine and front, top edge tinted red. First book appearance of a swashbuckling hero of old California, with the scarce dust jacket.Condition of this book:Good in good jacket. Jacket is chipped at edges and spine ends, crease in front panel. Boards show a few darkened areas and the cloth in the front joint is getting threadbare, overall sound. Shipments outside the U.S. may be subject to local taxes. Size: Octavo (standard book size). Text body is clean, and free from previous owner annotation, underlining and highlighting. Binding is tight, covers and spine fully intact. All edges clean, neat and free of foxing. Quantity Available: 1. Shipped Weight:… Read More

The Mark of Zorro

by McCULLEY, Johnston

Used

Very Good

Hardcover

Show Details

Description:

New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1938. Hardcover. Very Good/Good. Reprint edition. Stain on rear board, a very good copy in a good dustwrapper with shallow chips and tears, a stain on the rear panel, and a small scrape on the front panel. Jacket signed "Rary". A very scarce reprint, the first is exceptionally uncommon, and any early jacketed edition is very uncommon.

More Photos

The Mark of Zorro

by McCulley, Johnston

Used

Near Fine

Hardcover

Show Details

Description:

New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1924. Photoplay Edition. Hardcover. Near Fine. 8vo., 300pp. Sharp First Edition, bound in red cloth with titles in yellow on front board and spine. Originally published as "The Curse of Capistrano" in All-Story Weekly. The film was released in 1920 and then finally the novelization with G&D publishing both this First Edition and the Photoplay Edition published at about the same time. Square, tight and clean throughout with very light page toning and some off-setting to end-papers. Some minor wear and bumping to edges and tips. Some light spotting along the hinges. Lacking the very scarce dust-jacket. A very handsome collectable copy at a great price.

More Photos

The Mark of Zorro

by McCULLEY, Johnston

Used

Fine

Hardcover

first

Show Details

Description:

New York: Grosset and Dunlap, 1924. Hardcover. Fine. First edition. A fine copy, lacking the dustwrapper. The first book appearance of this story which originally appeared as a magazine serial, as a film, and finally appeared as a book. A beautiful copy.

More Photos

The Mark of Zorro (Photoplay Edition)

by McCulley, Johnston

Used

Near Fine

Hardcover

Show Details

Description:

New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1924. Photoplay Edition. Hardcover. Near Fine/Poor. 8vo., 300pp. plus 12pg publisher's catalogue in rear. Sharp Photoplay Edition, bound in red cloth with titles in gilt and outlined in black on front board and in black on the spine. 4 photo stills from the 1920 film starring Douglas Fairbanks. Originally published as "The Curse of Capistrano" in All-Story Weekly. The film was released and then finally the novelization with G&D publishing both the First Edition and this Photoplay Edition published at about the same time. Tight and clean throughout save a neat ownership signature on front paste-down. Little or no page toning and minor wear to spine ends and tips. A few spots of light toning to the bottom of the front board. Jacket has only front panel and flap still present with a partial split on the fold. Still colorful and presentable with what is left. A very handsome collectable copy and uncommon in any condition.

The Mark of Zorro

by McCulley, Johnston

Used

Near Fine

Hardcover

first

Show Details

Description:

New York: Grosset and Dunlap, 1924. First Edition. Hardcover. Near fine/very good. 1st edition. Near fine in a 1st printing jacket (having all points as above) with a chip at the base of the front panel, some wear, rubs, and 1 fold strengthened, otherwise very good. Grosset published mostly reprints, but not this one. There was a 1919, abridged version in All-Story Magazine titled The Curse of Capistrano, followed by an expansion of the story (McCulley, Eugene Miller and Douglas Fairbanks using his pen name, Elton Thomas) for the 1920 U. A. film and for our 1924 novel, but reports of a 1920 book edition are a hoax.

More Photos

THE MARK OF ZORRO

by McCulley, Johnston

Used

first

Show Details

Description:

THE MARK OF ZORRO, Grosset & Dunlap, 1924, first edition, spine extremities a bit lightened, age toning to the t.p.e.'s, else a bright, tight vg+ copy in an apparent first issue vg dust-wrapper with an equally bright pictorial front dust-wrapper panel with some chipping to the dust-wrapper spine extremities of the tanned dust-wrapper spine. The rear dust-wrapper panel also exhibits some tanning to both the upper fore edge margins. The photo-play edition with black & white stills from the film of the same name starring Douglas Fairbanks senior. Most uncommon in dust-wrapper.

The Mark of Zorro

by McCulley, Johnston

Used

Fine

Hardcover

first

Show Details

Description:

New York: Grosset and Dunlap, 1924. First Edition. Hardcover. fine/near fine. 1st edition of the California epic. Fine in the 1st printing dustjacket without the Grosset and Dunlap logo ("G&D") on the spine, and with Dec. 1924 ads on the verso. The dustjacket has small chips to the corners else it's near fine, and 1st editions of Zorro in the correct jacket are plenty scarce (despite us having 2 of them), and most copies in jacket are in the reprint jacket, and those few that are correct, usually look like they've been tortured by Torquemada and then shot by the Death Star. And copies without a jacket are just a submission to hasty expediency.
